https://www.bluerange.io/docs/opensource.text: ClcModule :: Fruitymesh Fruitymesh Quick Start Usage Features Developers Specification Modules AdvertisingModule DebugModule DfuModule EnrollmentModule IoModule MeshAccessModule Node ScanningModule StatusReporterModule Other Classes Logger RecordStorage Other Class Structure Debugging Battery Consumption RecordStorage The FruityMesh Algorithm In Detail Simulator Tutorials Implementing a Custom Module FAQ bluerange-firmware master bluerange-firmware master bluerange-firmware ClcModule The ClcModule contains the whole customer specific logic for regent. It works in conjunction with the ClcComm class that provides low level communication between FruityMesh and the regent controller. The component_sense and component_act messages are mapped to vendor specific data: Generic data Vendor Specific data nodeId Dest. (Destination Node) moduleId CLC_MODULE_ID (150) requestHandle cnt (Counter) actionType CMD (UNSPECIFIED ⇒ Not Mapped, ERROR_RSP ⇒ C0, READ_RSP ⇒ C1, WRITE_RSP ⇒ C2) component modbus Adr. (Modbus Device Address) registerAddress HR Adr. (Holding Register Address) payload Data The CR, length, Nr. HR, LF are automatically set or calculated from the data, the Source is automatically set using the nodeId of the sending device. Generic data Vendor Specific data nodeId Dest. (Destination Node) moduleId CLC_MODULE_ID (150) requestHandle cnt (Counter) actionType CMD (WRITE ⇒ D0, READ ⇒ D1, WRITE_ACK ⇒ D2) component modbus Adr. (Modbus Device Address) registerAddress HR Adr. (Holding Register Address) payload Either Data, or in case of READ mapped to Nr. HR The CR, length, LF are automatically set or calculated from the data, the Source is automatically set using the nodeId of the sending device. Example for Reading a Holding register TOPIC: rltn-iot/CEC820B9-F357-427B-801C-87335412E762/819E6137-5364-4695-A26A-9D6BABC78B7A/6AA262AE-B450-42BD-BE56-03BCC482F454/rwio/clc/21-4112/read { "module":"CLC_MODULE", "component":21, "register":4112, "length":2, "requestHandle":5, "timestamp":1559062507165 } Build with Antora

https://www.bluerange.io/docs/opensource.text: Regent / ClcModule :: Fruitymesh Fruitymesh Quick Start Usage Features Developers Specification Modules AdvertisingModule DebugModule DfuModule EnrollmentModule IoModule MeshAccessModule Node ScanningModule StatusReporterModule Other Classes Logger RecordStorage Other Class Structure Debugging Battery Consumption RecordStorage The FruityMesh Algorithm In Detail Simulator Tutorials Implementing a Custom Module FAQ bluerange-firmware master bluerange-firmware master bluerange-firmware Regent / ClcModule CLC (connected lighting controller) The code for regent is part of the ClcModule. Currently, the ClcModule uses the ClcComm for the UART Communication with the regent controller and the ClcAppConnection for communicating with the Tunable White App. For Specification of the Communication, look at: Pflichtenheft Software Connected Lighting Module v1.6-inWork4.pdf Software Definition Kommunikationsablauf App - Leuchte v1.3.pdf Internally, regent uses modbus, and we use a very similar structure to communicate with their controller and send that information to our cloud. prod_clc_mesh_nrf52 Runs on the clc module prod_clc_sink_nrf51 Special build necessary for the MeshGateway used by regent that can convert clc messages into json format (Should be made part of general sink) Do these steps in this order, otherwise, the CLC might get destroyed. Only plug in lamp power in the end! Attach the Connector to the plug near the BLE module (as shown in the picture). The "CPU" marking should point to the nearby cpu. Attach the clc to a debugger (Debugger must be switched off or disconnected from USB) Attach the clc to the lamp. Plug in the power of the lamp. Switch on the debugger. ⇒ When disconnecting, switch off Debugger first, then power off lamp. You can use Segger RTT to work with a terminal if activated because the UART is occupied and used between the two chips. Attach the debug connector to the other plug in the corner of the board Chipset is STM32F091CC (no optional bytes), SWD (speed 1000) Use JFlashLite 5.10u (Newer versions do not work with a nordic branded segger debugger) Flash the new binary You can also erase the board first, but the clcloader.hex has to be flashed first and then the new firmware You must reset the board manually (pressing the reset button on the debugger might work) Firmware updates can be .img, .bin, .hex. When flashing the CLC, the .hex has to be used. The one packaged in component updates is the .img version. The .bin version is only used when updating the lamp with the batch files from regent. To test the firmware update, FruityDeploy can be used to flash the update binary on the node directly. //FruityDeploy flashing: dfuparams --args dev_clc_mesh_nrf52 --dfuimage clm-01.12.XX-4b344bbf-rel.img --dfuparams 0 61440 65 //To test the update request clc updatereq 15 //To start the update for testing //params: , , clc update 15 266240 61440 Build with Antora

It works in conjunction with the VsComm class that provides low level communication between FruityMesh and the vossloh controller. The component_sense and component_act messages are mapped to vendor specific data: Generic data Vendor Specific data nodeId Destination ID moduleId VS_MODULE_ID (151) requestHandle Packet ID (requestHandle) actionType Packet (UNSPECIFIED ⇒ PT_EVENT, ERROR_RSP ⇒ Not Mapped, READ_RSP ⇒ Not Mapped, WRITE_RSP ⇒ PT_RSP) component Byte 0: Mapped to inputNum for PT_EVENT, 0 for other Packet Types; Byte 1: Reserved 0; (Little Endian) registerAddress Byte 0: Mapped to Encryption Type; Byte 1: Mapped to evtId or cmdId depending on Packet Type; (Little Endian) payload Data (Without cmdId, evtId and inputNum) Other data in the frame is set to fixed values or calculated. There is currently no mapping provided. Build with Antora

https://www.bluerange.io/docs/opensource.text: General :: Fruitymesh Fruitymesh Quick Start Usage Features Developers Specification Modules AdvertisingModule DebugModule DfuModule EnrollmentModule IoModule MeshAccessModule Node ScanningModule StatusReporterModule Other Classes Logger RecordStorage Other Class Structure Debugging Battery Consumption RecordStorage The FruityMesh Algorithm In Detail Simulator Tutorials Implementing a Custom Module FAQ bluerange-firmware master bluerange-firmware master bluerange-firmware General When sending code to waldmann, refer to ../mway/Generate-Distributions.adoc. dev_wm_nrf52840 Development build for waldmann including logging and everything else. Connecting the devboard to USB via its USB/UART connector (1) will power the board. Connecting it via the multiple Jlink adaptors (2) allows us to flash the nRF52840 chip. 1: USB / Serial adapter and board power 2: Segger Jlink Connection 3: MicroSd card reader for firmware updates 4: BLE module with button and rotary encorders 5: Waldmann host controller ATSAMD51N19A on main board (BLE module can also be plugged in here 6: Multiple serial sockets 7: Development PCB with some buttons and connectors Each of the module sockets (black) or the serial cable sockets (white) on the main board (5) are connected to the host controller and have a specific (src/dst) id. The host controller will do routing between these ids. The Waldmann controller does not need to be flashed, but will be updated using the microSd card reader. When using the button firmware update, the update will be done each time, downgrade and the same version will work as well. Put the microSd in a PC card reader Copy the firmware update to \WA\IMAGE (E.g. the file is V00_01_s.bin) Unplug the serial adapter (1) Put the microSd card into the card reader (3) hold down the blue button on the host controller PCB (5) and plug in the serial adapter, then let go of the blue button after a second. The LED on the host controller board should be on and stay on for about 15 to 20 seconds. Afterwards, it will go off. For Waldmann the profileId is used as the register and the nodeAddress (e.g. 0x00 for the main controller) is used to address the attached device that should react on this profile. The actionType is currently unused as the profiles do not have a direction distinction. The following message can be used to switch an LED off: rltn-iot/ORGANIZATION_UUID/SITE_UUID/BLENODE_UUID/rwio/WM_MODULE/0-4194/write { "register":4194, "data":"AAA=", "length":2, "module":"WM_MODULE", "component":0, "timestamp":12345 } Below are some helpful commands for testing //Activate LED 55 02 00 10 62 00 20 10 00 20 14 3B 6E //Ack for activate LED 55 01 00 00 A1 10 00 00 20 00 88 D2 //Tunnel message 55 05 00 90 62 00 20 10 00 00 00 00 00 77 89 41 //Sending tunnel data via terminal raw_data_light 0 155 0 62:90:20:00:00:10:77 //Fake LED message for testing led off 55 02 00 10 62 00 20 10 00 00 00 6F 3D //Fake LED message for testing led on 55 02 00 10 62 00 20 10 00 01 00 5C 0C //For reference component_act [nodeId] [moduleId] [actionType] [component] [registerAddress] [dataHex] //Switch the LED of the host on component_act 0 155 0 0x00 0x1062 02:14 //Switch the LED of the host off component_act 0 155 0 0x00 0x1062 00:00 //Reset the host (no ack) component_act 0 155 0 0x00 0x74 00 Build with Antora
